hints.content: Start by understanding the constraints on building heights. The first building must be of height 0, and the height difference between adjacent buildings cannot exceed 1.
Consider how the restrictions affect the heights of the buildings. Each restriction gives a maximum height for a specific building, which will limit how tall that building can be.
Remember that building heights must be non-negative integers. This means that any height calculated or assigned must be at least 0.
Since the height of building 1 is fixed at 0, think about how this influences the heights of subsequent buildings. The maximum height of building 2 can only be 1.
When processing the restrictions, sort them by building ID. This will help you determine the maximum possible height of buildings in order.
After sorting, you can iterate through the restrictions and calculate the maximum possible height for each building based on the previous building's height.
For each building, consider the maximum height allowed by the restriction and the height that can be built based on the previous building's height.
Pay attention to the gaps between buildings with restrictions. The heights of buildings between two restricted buildings must be adjusted to maintain the height difference constraint.
When there are no restrictions, the maximum height of the last building can be simply `n - 1` since you can increment the height by 1 for each building.
If there are restrictions, after processing all the restricted buildings, you should also consider the heights of the buildings after the last restriction up to building n.
Use a two-pass approach: first, calculate heights from left to right based on restrictions, and then from right to left to ensure all constraints are satisfied.
During the left-to-right pass, keep track of the maximum height you can achieve for each building without violating the height difference rule.
In the right-to-left pass, do the same but ensure that the heights do not exceed the maximum heights set by the restrictions.
After both passes, the tallest building's height will be the maximum value found in your height array. Make sure to check all buildings for the final answer.
Finally, consider edge cases such as when there are no restrictions at all or when all buildings have the same maximum height restriction.

questionNotes: Building 1 has a fixed height of 0.
Height difference between adjacent buildings cannot exceed 1.
Restrictions are given as pairs [id, maxHeight], where id is unique and not equal to 1.
The maximum number of restrictions is min(n - 1, 10^5).
Return the maximum possible height of the tallest building.
